data.title: Add missing pt-BR locale key
Checking for updates and installing them
data.body:
`server/index.ts` can be invoked in one of two ways: through the command line, or through the app
- [x] `node server registry`
- [x] `node server update core` and `node server update core@${version}`
- [x] `node server update ${systemID}`
- [x] Check if we're in the dev version (`.git` exists) in core and systems
- [x] Make sure we download to temporary locations and only delete after everything has been successfully downloaded
## `node server registry`

This command should fetch the registry and annotate it with what versions of each system or plugin are installed, if any, and for those, also fetch the latest version number. It should also display systems and plugins installed but not found in the registry!

In command-line mode, this should be pretty-printed  
When access from the app, it should send the resulting JSON with `process.send()`.
## `node server update core`

This command should fetch the latest core version and compare with current installed.

In command-line mode, it should offer updating, maybe using [inquirer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/inquirer).
From the app, it should just return the installed and latest version numbers with `process.send()` and exit.

if a version number is passed with `@version`, then the update should happen right away without awaiting confirmation. This will be used by the app.
## `node server update system`

Update a system and all of its installed plugins. As previously established, `common` and `default` plugins are always installed and cannot be removed. (It will be possible to enable/disable `default` plugins per-project later).

In command-line mode, it should offer updating, maybe using [inquirer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/inquirer).
From the app, it should just do the updates right away.

(Later on, we can have a more complex syntax with `node server update system:author/plugin@version`, but it seems overkill for now.)

data.title: Server crash if you move a folder
data.body:
I just created a new project. I created one folder named 'documentation' and after that a second folder named 'assets'. The folder 'assets' appeared in the tree under 'documentation'. As I moved the 'asset'-folder in the main tree the server crashed.
Server: Superpowers node 0.19.0 @ Linux Debian 8
Client: Superpowers app 0.19.0 @ Windows 7 Ultimate

data.title: "Error: The system game is not installed." <-- add howto fix hint
data.body:
Could you extend this error message to show the suggested next steps to investigate or fix it? A URL to the FAQ or an issue thread might suffice.

``` text
The server crashed while loading project "pac-man-like-game".
Error: The system game is not installed.
    at done (/…/sp-dev/core/server/ProjectServer.js:122:30)
    at /…/sp-dev/core/server/ProjectServer.js:149:17
    at tryToString (fs.js:414:3)
    at FSReqWrap.readFileAfterClose [as oncomplete] (fs.js:401:12)
```

``` text
Devel environment: Node.js v5.7.1, npm v3.6.0, Ubuntu 12.04.5 LTS precise
sp-dev/app = superpowers/superpowers-app @ d0af9ed: Make travis notify gitter
sp-dev/core = superpowers/superpowers-core @ 2f266e9: SupClient: Store client ID on ProjectClient
sp-dev/core/systems/game = superpowers/superpowers-game @ d1ce643: scene: Allow dropping scene in a prefab again. Fixes #79
sp-dev/proj/pac-man-like-game = superpowers-extra/pac-man-like-game @ 89c10e0: Create README.md
```

**Update:** Another worthy hint would be which expectation failed, e.g.

> Unable to read ~/.local/share/Superpowers/systems/game/package.json

By chance I noticed that there's an empty directory `~/.local/share/Superpowers/systems/`, so in there I symlinked the `game` directory from `~/.local/share/Superpowers/core/systems/` (note the inserted `core/`):

``` bash
cd sp-dev/home/.local/share/Superpowers/systems
ln --symbolic --target-directory=. ../core/systems/game
```

And now the server successfully starts.

data.title: While building: npm WARN deprecated graceful-fs@3.0.8
data.body:
While building 2f266e9a7948c1ff24b97ffd8f251fca785944ab with Node.js v5.7.1, npm v3.6.0 on Ubuntu 12.04.5 LTS precise:

> npm WARN deprecated graceful-fs@3.0.8: graceful-fs version 3 and before will fail on newer node releases. Please update to graceful-fs@^4.0.0 as soon as possible.

data.title: client: Browser tab doesn't have proper title when opening asset from a link
data.body:
It works when opening the asset from the main window with the button.

We should add a `setupWindowTitle` function on SupClient to do the job. It will take the projectClient and the id of the asset as parameters. It must subscribe to the entries through the projectClient to recover the name and update the document's title.

See https://github.com/superpowers/superpowers-core/blob/master/client/src/project/index.ts#L982 and https://github.com/superpowers/superpowers-game/blob/master/plugins/default/sprite/componentEditors/SpriteRendererEditor.ts#L177 + https://github.com/superpowers/superpowers-game/blob/master/plugins/default/sprite/componentEditors/SpriteRendererEditor.ts#L257

data.title: Assets._load: TypeError: Cannot read property 'data' of undefined
data.body:
When launching the IDE, the log below the "Servers" page shows:

``` text
The server crashed while loading project "…".
TypeError: Cannot read property 'data' of undefined
    at Assets._load (…/sph/resources/app/SupCore/Data/Assets.js:25:44)
    at Assets.Dictionary.acquire (…/sph/resources/app/SupCore/Data/Base/Dictionary.js:33:29)
    at Assets.acquire (…/sph/resources/app/SupCore/Data/Assets.js:20:34)
    at …/sph/resources/app/server/ProjectServer.js:227:35
    at …/sph/resources/app/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:181:20
    at Object.async.forEachOf.async.eachOf (…/sph/resources/app/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:233:13)
    at Object.async.forEach.async.each (…/sph/resources/app/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:209:22)
    at ProjectServer.prepareAssets (…/sph/resources/app/server/ProjectServer.js:221:19)
    at …/sph/resources/app/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:718:13
    at Immediate.iterate [as _onImmediate] (…/sph/resources/app/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:262:13)
```

First step to debugging would be a better error message. My node is too old to build the dev version and make a proper PR, so here's my patch:

``` diff
--- resources/app/SupCore/Data/Assets.js.v0.19.0
+++ resources/app/SupCore/Data/Assets.js
@@ -21,8 +21,9 @@
     };
     Assets.prototype._load = function (id) {
         var _this = this;
         var entry = this.server.data.entries.byId[id];
+        if (!this.server.system) { throw new Error("No server.system?"); }
         var assetClass = this.server.system.data.assetClasses[entry.type];
         if (assetClass == null)
             throw new Error("No data plugin for asset type \"" + entry.type + "\"");
         var asset = new assetClass(id, null, this.server);
```

Launching the IDE again shows that this was the problem:

``` text
The server crashed while loading project "…".
Error: No server.system?
    at Assets._load (…/sph/resources/app/SupCore/Data/Assets.js:25:42)
```

I hope the docs will tell me where to get a proper `server.system`.

data.title: feature idea: Incorporate yarn into superpowers
data.body:
What is yarn:
https://github.com/InfiniteAmmoInc/Yarn

Dialogue editor created for "Night in the Woods" (and other projects) by @NoelFB and @infinite_ammo with contributions from @seiyria and @beeglebug. It is heavily inspired by and based on the amazing Twine software: http://twinery.org/

It can output a simple json file which can then be parsed as dialogue/logic in games - that is interactive.

Yarn is in html5, so it is possible to add it to superpowers and give it the superpower to be collaborative! 
try online: http://infiniteammo.com/yarn/

Having a yarn parser API in superpowers will make it easy to create adventure/rpg style games that rely heavily on story.
Currently there is a parser written in C#:
https://github.com/thesecretlab/YarnSpinner
it works on unity, since the games that yarn was used it run on unity. This is needed in order to be able to actually use yarn created dialogue/logic in your game.

So having Yarn in Superpowers will actually improve yarn in two ways:
- it will allow more than one user to simultaneously work on a Yarn file and together write their game's story.
- It will allow the developer to use yarn and yarn created dialogue without leaving the game engine - yarn editor being embedded in the game editor would allow that.

Having Yarn in superpowers would improve superpowers too:
- It will make it a more viable choice to make adventure style games in - as it will make it much easier to develop such type of games
- It could also potentially be used as a state machine - yarn's c# parser for example can take yarn json commands and parse them to trigger executing a function, changing a variable and all sorts of different things. Yarn dialogue boxes can also have a set of conditions in order to be triggered.
  Paired with the interface of yarn editor - one can easily see it as a state machine editor, just as much as an interactive dialogue editor. Yarn syntax is very easy to understand:
  https://github.com/thesecretlab/YarnSpinner/blob/master/Documentation/Usage.md

data.title: Add scrollbars on Tilesets / Tilemaps previews
data.body:
Hi,

It would be interesting to add scrollbars on the "preview part" on the right, for Tilesets / Tilemaps because for now I have to zoom / unzoom on some areas to focus on the part I want to add / edit.

data.title: Headless server not connecting
data.body:
### What I've Done

I downloaded the 64-bit linux version of Superpowers, extracted it on my 14.04 Ubuntu server and followed the directions at the bottom of [this page](http://docs.superpowers-html5.com/en/getting-started/setting-up-superpowers). The directions are slightly wrong, as it asks you to use 'cd resources/app' and then run 'node app/server start' which should read 'node server start'. The server turns on successfully. I forwarded ports 4237-8.
### The Problem
- The page successfully loads with the project interface, but at the center of the window it reads "Connecting..."
- The following errors shows up in the Chrome console: [image](http://puu.sh/nnJ6J/f64bb5f50b.jpg),
  followed by a failed Socket.io connection every 5 seconds or so.
- Connecting using the desktop client does not work either.

data.title: "Output folder must be empty" when exporting on Ubuntu 12.04
data.body:
Hello,

I am using superpowers-0.19.0-linux-x64 under ubuntu 12.04.
I have followed the first tutorial and wanted to test it on my server.
Everything seems to be fine except the "publish" function, I only get "Output folder must be empty" message although directory has just been created.

Please advise.
Yanik

data.title: Automatically replace "x.0" with "x" when entering numbers
data.body:
When entering numbers (example : coordinates in the scene editor), "x.0" should be automatically replaced with "x".
Mathematically they are the same and therefore it shouldn't change anything.

data.title: Shrink/Grow cannon body to 3D model body
data.body:
(Feature request; or request for documentation if this function is already there.)

If the cannon dimensions/offset are too small/wrong my object keeps sinking into the floor; if too large/wrong my object is floating, and acts like there is a force-field around it. That flexibility is great, but 99% of the time we just want the physics to match the physical appearance, and have the cannon body be exactly the dimensions of the model.

(I'm having loads of trouble getting the cannon dimensions to fit - a cycle of add/subtract 0.1 from any of the 6 offsets/dimensions then run the game again and test collisions, over and over... I feel I must be missing something!!)

data.title: Remove scheduled save when during asset deletion, closes #90
data.body: Added code inside the asset deletion method to remove the pending callback from the scheduled save.

data.title: Use and recommend Node.js 5.x
data.body:
We've been recommending that people use Node.js 4.x because of potential issues with native modules at the time. But Superpowers currently runs just fine on Node.js 5.x and, as a matter of fact, Electron v0.36 ships with Node.js 5.x anyway so it's probably best to be using a similar version of everywhere.

So we should update `travis.yml` in all repositories to use Node.js 5.x, upgrade our local installs of Node.js and update the documentation (https://github.com/superpowers/docs.superpowers-html5.com/blob/master/pages/en/4_development/3_building-superpowers.md) too.

As a bonus, it ships with npm@3 by default!

data.title: Support single port configuration and SSL
data.body: Fix for #105

data.title: Fix typo in Swedish translation and add "filter"
Support hosting the server on a single port and over https
data.body: In order to be more flexible about server hosting options. Requiring two ports makes it more difficult to host with shared hosting providers in case you don't want it running on your local machine.

Add possibility to delete a project as mentioned on issue #99.
Feel free to criticize the code, it's my first "real" contribution.

data.title: hub: Allow deleting a project from the client UI
data.body:
My personal bias would go towards only unloading the project from the server and renaming its folder on disk to something like `${projectSlug}.deleted` (Project folder names containing dots [are ignored](https://github.com/superpowers/superpowers/blob/0840b1f95a9ade091892aba6b55522fd8af581a7/server/ProjectHub.ts#L29) when the server starts up), rather than deleting it altogether, because that would be an irreversible operation and it's safest if people do it through familiar channels like their Explorer/Finder or shell.

I think until authentication and access rights as laid out in #55 are in, we should only enable it for passwordless local-only servers (because letting anyone with the server password delete projects seems like too much power).
